                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     In February 2020, Clapton and Winwood played a selection of firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder material at a tribute gig to Baker at the Eventim Apollo.[43]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Notes\n firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was an American rock band that initially performed and recorded in the late 1960s and early 1970s and was sporadically active until 2009. Based in San Francisco, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder played in a psychedelic blues rock or acid rock style, and are also credited as being some of the earliest pioneers of heavy metal, with their cover of "Summertime firstnameplaceholders" sometimes cited as the first in the genre.[7] They have also been noted as influential in the development of genres as disparate as punk rock,[8] stoner rock,[9][10] doom metal,[10] experimental rock,[11] and grunge.[12]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   "firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder" was the name of a variety of LSD made by chemist and Grateful Dead patron Owsley Stanley[13] and the band was probably named after that, although the name existed earlier, as the name of a laundry detergent[14] after which the LSD variety itself was named.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * The 2007 Japanese mini-LP sleeve reissue of firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder contains the mono non-LP single "All Night Long" b/w "Fortunes" along with the single versions of "Fool" and "Ain't That The Way" as bonus tracks.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     * The 2007 Japanese mini-LP sleeve reissue of firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder contains the mono non-LP single "All Night Long" b/w "Fortunes" along with the single versions of "Fool" and "Ain't That The Way" as bonus tracks.\n                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Ellas McDaniel (born Ellas Otha Bates; December 30, 1928 – June 2, 2008), known as firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, was an American singer, guitarist, songwriter and music producer who played a key role in the transition from the blues to rock and roll. He influenced many artists, including Buddy Holly,[1] Elvis Presley,[2] the Beatles, the Rolling Stones,[3] the Animals, and the Clash.[4]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              His use of African rhythms and a signature beat, a simple five-accent hambone rhythm, is a cornerstone of hip hop, rock, and pop music.[3][5][6] In recognition of his achievements, he was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1987, the Blues Hall of Fame in 2003, and the Rhythm and Blues Music Hall of Fame in 2017.[7][5][8] He received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Rhythm and Blues Foundation and the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award.[9] secondnameplaceholder is also recognized for his technical innovations, including his distinctive rectangular guitar, with its unique booming, resonant, shimmering tones.[10][citation needed]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Ellas McDaniel (born Ellas Otha Bates; December 30, 1928 – June 2, 2008), known as firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, was an American singer, guitarist, songwriter and music producer who played a key role in the transition from the blues to rock and roll. He influenced many artists, including Buddy Holly,[1] Elvis Presley,[2] the Beatles, the Rolling Stones,[3] the Animals, and the Clash.[4]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              His use of African rhythms and a signature beat, a simple five-accent hambone rhythm, is a cornerstone of hip hop, rock, and pop music.[3][5][6] In recognition of his achievements, he was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1987, the Blues Hall of Fame in 2003, and the Rhythm and Blues Music Hall of Fame in 2017.[7][5][8] He received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Rhythm and Blues Foundation and the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award.[9] secondnameplaceholder is also recognized for his technical innovations, including his distinctive rectangular guitar, with its unique booming, resonant, shimmering tones.[10][citation needed]\n
 firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was posthumously awarded a Doctor of Fine Arts degree by the University of Florida for his influence on American popular music. In its People in America radio series, about influential people in American history, the Voice of America radio service paid tribute to him, describing how "his influence was so widespread that it is hard to imagine what rock and roll would have sounded like without him." Mick Jagger stated that "he was a wonderful, original musician who was an enormous force in music and was a big influence on the Rolling Stones. He was very generous to us in our early years and we learned a lot from him". Jagger also praised the late star as a one-of-a-kind musician, adding, "We will never see his like again".[64] The documentary film Cheat You Fair: The Story of Maxwell Street by director Phil Ranstrom features firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's last on-camera interview.[65]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   He achieved numerous accolades in recognition of his significant role as one of the founding fathers of rock and roll.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   In 2003, U.S. Representative John Conyers paid tribute to firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder in the United States House of Representatives, describing him as "one of the true pioneers of rock and roll, who has influenced generations".[70]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    In 2004, Mickey and Sylvia's 1956 recording of "Love Is Strange" (a song first recorded by firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder but not released until a year before his death) was inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame as a recording of qualitative or historical significance. Also in 2004, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was inducted into the Blues Foundation's Blues Hall of Fame and was ranked number 20 on Rolling Stone magazine's list of the 100 Greatest Artists of All Time.[71]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     In 2005, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder celebrated his 50th anniversary in music with successful tours of Australia and Europe and with coast-to-coast shows across North America. He performed his song "firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder" with Eric Clapton and Robbie Robertson at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's 20th annual induction ceremony. In the UK, Uncut magazine included his 1957 debut album, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, in its listing of the '100 Music, Movie & TV Moments That Have Changed the World'.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was honored by the Mississippi Blues Commission with a Mississippi Blues Trail historic marker placed in McComb, his birthplace, in recognition of his enormous contribution to the development of the blues in Mississippi.[72] On June 5, 2009, the city of Gainesville, Florida, officially renamed and dedicated its downtown plaza the firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder Community Plaza. The plaza was the site of a benefit concert at which firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder performed to raise awareness about the plight of the homeless in Alachua County and to raise money for local charities, including the Red Cross.\n                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder (born Robert Allen Zimmerman; May 24, 1941) is an American singer-songwriter, author and visual artist. Often regarded as one of the greatest songwriters of all time,[3] secondnameplaceholder has been a major figure in popular culture during a career spanning nearly 60 years. Much of his most celebrated work dates from the 1960s, when songs such as "Blowin' in the Wind" (1963) and "The Times They Are a-Changin'" (1964) became anthems for the civil rights and anti-war movements. His lyrics during this period incorporated a range of political, social, philosophical, and literary influences, defying pop music conventions and appealing to the burgeoning counterculture.[4]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                            Following his self-titled debut album in 1962, which mainly comprised traditional folk songs, secondnameplaceholder made his breakthrough as a songwriter with the release of The Freewheelin' firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder the following year. The album features "Blowin' in the Wind" and the thematically complex "A Hard Rain's a-Gonna Fall". For many of these songs, he adapted the tunes and phraseology of older folk songs. He went on to release the politically charged The Times They Are a-Changin' and the more lyrically abstract and introspective Another Side of firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder in 1964. In 1965 and 1966, secondnameplaceholder drew controversy when he adopted electrically amplified rock instrumentation, and in the space of 15 months recorded three of the most important and influential rock albums of the 1960s: Bringing It All Back Home (1965), Highway 61 Revisited (1965) and Blonde on Blonde (1966). Commenting on the six-minute single "Like a Rolling Stone" (1965), Rolling Stone wrote: "No other pop song has so thoroughly challenged and transformed the commercial laws and artistic conventions of its time, for all time."[5]\n
                                                                                                                    In July 1966, secondnameplaceholder withdrew from touring after a motorcycle accident. During this period, he recorded a large body of songs with members of the Band, who had previously backed him on tour. These recordings were released as the collaborative album The Basement Tapes in 1975. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, secondnameplaceholder explored country music and rural themes in John Wesley Harding (1967), Nashville Skyline (1969), and New Morning (1970). In 1975, he released Blood on the Tracks, which many saw as a return to form. In the late 1970s, he became a born-again Christian and released a series of albums of contemporary gospel music before returning to his more familiar rock-based idiom in the early 1980s. secondnameplaceholder's 1997 album Time Out of Mind marked the beginning of a renaissance for his career. He has released five critically acclaimed albums of original material since then, the most recent being Rough and Rowdy Ways (2020). He also recorded a series of three albums in the 2010s comprising versions of traditional American standards, especially songs recorded by Frank Sinatra. Backed by a changing lineup of musicians, he has toured steadily since the late 1980s on what has been dubbed the Never Ending Tour.[6]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Since 1994, secondnameplaceholder has published eight books of drawings and paintings, and his work has been exhibited in major art galleries. He has sold more than 100 million records, making him one of the best-selling musicians of all time. He has received numerous awards, including the Presidential Medal of Freedom, ten Grammy Awards, a Golden Globe Award and an Academy Award. secondnameplaceholder has been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame and the Songwriters Hall of Fame. The Pulitzer Prize Board in 2008 awarded him a special citation for "his profound impact on popular music and American culture, marked by lyrical compositions of extraordinary poetic power". In 2016, secondnameplaceholder was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature "for having created new poetic expressions within the great American song tradition".[7]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          In May 1963, secondnameplaceholder's political profile rose when he walked out of The Ed Sullivan Show. During rehearsals, secondnameplaceholder had been told by CBS television's head of program practices that "Talkin' John Birch Paranoid Blues" was potentially libelous to the John Birch Society. Rather than comply with censorship, secondnameplaceholder refused to appear.[69]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       By this time, secondnameplaceholder and Baez were prominent in the civil rights movement, singing together at the March on Washington on August 28, 1963.[70] secondnameplaceholder's third album, The Times They Are a-Changin', reflected a more politicized secondnameplaceholder.[71] The songs often took as their subject matter contemporary stories, with "Only a Pawn in Their Game" addressing the murder of civil rights worker Medgar Evers; and the Brechtian "The Lonesome Death of Hattie Carroll" the death of black hotel barmaid Hattie Carroll, at the hands of young white socialite William Zantzinger.[72] On a more general theme, "Ballad of Hollis Brown" and "North Country Blues" addressed despair engendered by the breakdown of farming and mining communities. This political material was accompanied by two personal love songs, "Boots of Spanish Leather" and "One Too Many Mornings".[73]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    By the end of 1963, secondnameplaceholder felt both manipulated and constrained by the folk and protest movements.[74] Accepting the "Tom Paine Award" from the National Emergency Civil Liberties Committee shortly after the assassination of John F. Kennedy, an intoxicated secondnameplaceholder questioned the role of the committee, characterized the members as old and balding, and claimed to see something of himself and of every man in Kennedy's assassin, Lee Harvey Oswald.[75]\n
 In July 1965, secondnameplaceholder's six-minute single "Like a Rolling Stone" peaked at number two in the U.S. chart. In 2004 and in 2011, Rolling Stone listed it as number one of "The 500 Greatest Songs of All Time".[5][100] Bruce Springsteen, in his speech for secondnameplaceholder's inauguration into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, said that on first hearing the single, "that snare shot sounded like somebody'd kicked open the door to your mind."[101] The song opened secondnameplaceholder's next album, Highway 61 Revisited, named after the road that led from secondnameplaceholder's Minnesota to the musical hotbed of New Orleans.[102] The songs were in the same vein as the hit single, flavored by Mike Bloomfield's blues guitar and Al Kooper's organ riffs. "Desolation Row", backed by acoustic guitar and understated bass,[103] offers the sole exception, with secondnameplaceholder alluding to figures in Western culture in a song described by Andy Gill as "an 11-minute epic of entropy, which takes the form of a Fellini-esque parade of grotesques and oddities featuring a huge cast of celebrated characters, some historical (Einstein, Nero), some biblical (Noah, Cain and Abel), some fictional (Ophelia, Romeo, Cinderella), some literary (T. S. Eliot and Ezra Pound), and some who fit into none of the above categories, notably Dr. Filth and his dubious nurse".[104]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           secondnameplaceholder's next release, Nashville Skyline (1969) featured Nashville musicians, a mellow-voiced secondnameplaceholder, a duet with Johnny Cash, and the single "Lay Lady Lay".[132] Variety wrote, "secondnameplaceholder is definitely doing something that can be called singing. Somehow he has managed to add an octave to his range."[133] During one recording session, secondnameplaceholder and Cash recorded a series of duets but only their version of secondnameplaceholder's "Girl from the North Country" was released on the album.[134][135]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              In May 1969, secondnameplaceholder appeared on the first episode of Johnny Cash's television show and sang a duet with Cash of "Girl from the North Country", with solos of "Living the Blues" and "I Threw It All Away".[136] secondnameplaceholder next traveled to England to top the bill at the Isle of Wight festival on August 31, 1969, after rejecting overtures to appear at the Woodstock Festival closer to his home.[137]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           In the early 1970s, critics charged that secondnameplaceholder's output was varied and unpredictable. Rolling Stone writer Greil Marcus asked "What is this shit?" on first listening to Self Portrait, released in June 1970.[138][139] It was a double LP including few original songs, and was poorly received.[140] In October 1970, secondnameplaceholder released New Morning, considered a return to form.[141] This album included "Day of the Locusts", a song in which secondnameplaceholder gave an account of receiving an honorary degree from Princeton University on June 9, 1970.[142] In November 1968, secondnameplaceholder had co-written "I'd Have You Anytime" with George Harrison;[143] Harrison recorded "I'd Have You Anytime" and secondnameplaceholder's "If Not for You" for his 1970 solo triple album All Things Must Pass. secondnameplaceholder's surprise appearance at Harrison's 1971 Concert for Bangladesh attracted media coverage, reflecting that secondnameplaceholder's live appearances had become rare.[144]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Between March 16 and 19, 1971, secondnameplaceholder reserved three days at Blue Rock, a small studio in Greenwich Village, to record with Leon Russell. These sessions resulted in "Watching the River Flow" and a new recording of "When I Paint My Masterpiece".[145] On November 4, 1971, secondnameplaceholder recorded "George Jackson", which he released a week later. For many, the single was a surprising return to protest material, mourning the killing of Black Panther George Jackson in San Quentin State Prison that year.[146] secondnameplaceholder contributed piano and harmony to Steve Goodman's album, Somebody Else's Troubles, under the pseudonym Robert Milkwood Thomas (referencing Under Milk Wood by secondnameplaceholder Thomas and his own previous name) in September 1972.[147]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 In 1972, secondnameplaceholder signed to Sam Peckinpah's film Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid, providing songs and backing music for the movie, and playing "Alias", a member of Billy's gang with some historical basis.[148] Despite the film's failure at the box office, the song "Knockin' on Heaven's Door" became one of secondnameplaceholder's most covered songs.[149][150]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 Also in 1972, secondnameplaceholder protested the move to deport John Lennon and Yoko Ono, who had been convicted of possessing cannabis, by sending a letter to the U.S. Immigration Service, in part: "Hurray for John & Yoko. Let them stay and live here and breathe. The country's got plenty of room and space. Let John and Yoko stay!"[151]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         After the tour, secondnameplaceholder and his wife became estranged. He filled a small red notebook with songs about relationships and ruptures, and recorded an album titled Blood on the Tracks in September 1974.[161] secondnameplaceholder delayed the release and re-recorded half of the songs at Sound 80 Studios in Minneapolis with production assistance from his brother, David Zimmerman.[162]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Released in early 1975, Blood on the Tracks received mixed reviews. In the NME, Nick Kent described the "accompaniments" as "often so trashy they sound like mere practice takes".[163] In Rolling Stone, Jon Landau wrote that "the record has been made with typical shoddiness."[163] Over the years critics came to see it as one of secondnameplaceholder's greatest achievements. For the Salon website, journalist Bill Wyman wrote: "Blood on the Tracks is his only flawless album and his best produced; the songs, each of them, are constructed in disciplined fashion. It is his kindest album and most dismayed, and seems in hindsight to have achieved a sublime balance between the logorrhea-plagued excesses of his mid-1960s output and the self-consciously simple compositions of his post-accident years".[164] Novelist Rick Moody called it "the truest, most honest account of a love affair from tip to stern ever put down on magnetic tape".[165]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                            In the late 1970s, secondnameplaceholder converted to Evangelical Christianity,[185][186] undertaking a three-month discipleship course run by the Association of Vineyard Churches;[187][188] and released three albums of contemporary gospel music. Slow Train Coming (1979) featured the guitar accompaniment of Mark Knopfler (of Dire Straits) and was produced by veteran R&B producer Jerry Wexler. Wexler said that secondnameplaceholder had tried to evangelize him during the recording. He replied: "firstnameplaceholder, you're dealing with a 62-year-old Jewish atheist. Let's just make an album."[189] secondnameplaceholder won the Grammy Award for Best Male Rock Vocal Performance for the song "Gotta Serve Somebody". His second Christian-themed album, Saved (1980), received mixed reviews, described by Michael Gray as "the nearest thing to a follow-up album secondnameplaceholder has ever made, Slow Train Coming II and inferior".[190] His third overtly Christian album was Shot of Love in 1981.[191] When touring in late 1979 and early 1980, secondnameplaceholder would not play his older, secular works, and he delivered declarations of his faith from the stage, such as:\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            secondnameplaceholder's Christianity was unpopular with some fans and musicians.[193] Shortly before his murder, John Lennon recorded "Serve Yourself" in response to secondnameplaceholder's "Gotta Serve Somebody".[194] By 1981, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times that "neither age (he's now 40) nor his much-publicized conversion to born-again Christianity has altered his essentially iconoclastic temperament".[195]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       In late 1980, secondnameplaceholder briefly played concerts billed as "A Musical Retrospective", restoring popular 1960s songs to the repertoire. Shot of Love, recorded early the next year, featured his first secular compositions in more than two years, mixed with Christian songs. "Every Grain of Sand" reminded some of William Blake's verses.[196]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 secondnameplaceholder commenced the 2000s by winning the Polar Music Prize in May 2000 and his first Oscar; his song "Things Have Changed", written for the film Wonder Boys, won an Academy Award for Best Song in 2001.[241] The Oscar, by some reports a facsimile, tours with him, presiding over shows atop an amplifier.[242]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     "Love and Theft" was released on September 11, 2001. Recorded with his touring band, secondnameplaceholder produced the album himself under the pseudonym Jack Frost.[243] The album was critically well received and earned nominations for several Grammy awards.[244] Critics noted that secondnameplaceholder was widening his musical palette to include rockabilly, Western swing, jazz, and even lounge ballads.[245] "Love and Theft" generated controversy when The Wall Street Journal pointed out similarities between the album's lyrics and Japanese author Junichi Saga's book Confessions of a Yakuza.[246][247]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In 2003, secondnameplaceholder revisited the evangelical songs from his Christian period and participated in the CD project Gotta Serve Somebody: The Gospel Songs of firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder. That year secondnameplaceholder also released the film Masked & Anonymous, which he co-wrote with director Larry Charles under the alias Sergei Petrov.[248] secondnameplaceholder played the central character in the film, Jack Fate, alongside a cast that included Jeff Bridges, Penélope Cruz and John Goodman. The film polarised critics: many dismissed it as an "incoherent mess";[249][250] a few treated it as a serious work of art.[251][252]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            In October 2004, secondnameplaceholder published the first part of his autobiography, Chronicles: Volume One. Confounding expectations,[253] secondnameplaceholder devoted three chapters to his first year in New York City in 1961–1962, virtually ignoring the mid-1960s when his fame was at its height. He also devoted chapters to the albums New Morning (1970) and Oh Mercy (1989). The book reached number two on The New York Times' Hardcover Non-Fiction best seller list in December 2004 and was nominated for a National Book Award.[254]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   No Direction Home, Martin Scorsese's acclaimed film biography of secondnameplaceholder,[255] was first broadcast on September 26–27, 2005, on BBC Two in the UK and PBS in the US.[256] The documentary focuses on the period from secondnameplaceholder's arrival in New York in 1961 to his motorcycle crash in 1966, featuring interviews with Suze Rotolo, Liam Clancy, Joan Baez, Allen Ginsberg, Pete Seeger, Mavis Staples and secondnameplaceholder himself. The film received a Peabody Award in April 2006[257] and a Columbia-duPont Award in January 2007.[258] The accompanying soundtrack featured unreleased songs from secondnameplaceholder's early career.[259]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   secondnameplaceholder's career as a radio presenter commenced on May 3, 2006, with his weekly radio program, Theme Time Radio Hour for XM Satellite Radio, with song selections on chosen themes.[260][261] secondnameplaceholder played classic and obscure records from the 1920s to the present day, including contemporary artists as diverse as Blur, Prince, L.L. Cool J and the Streets. The show was praised by fans and critics, as secondnameplaceholder told stories and made eclectic references, commenting on his musical choices.[262][263] In April 2009, secondnameplaceholder broadcast the 100th show in his radio series; the theme was "Goodbye" and the final record played was Woody Guthrie's "So Long, It's Been Good to Know Yuh".[264]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       secondnameplaceholder resurrected his Theme Time Radio Hour format when he broadcast a two-hour special on the theme of "Whiskey" on Sirius Radio on September 21, 2020.[265]\n               Robert Nesta secondnameplaceholder, OM (6 February 1945 – 11 May 1981) was a Jamaican singer, songwriter, and musician. Considered one of the pioneers of reggae, his musical career was marked by fusing elements of reggae, ska, and rocksteady, as well as his distinctive vocal and songwriting style.[2][3] secondnameplaceholder's contributions to music increased the visibility of Jamaican music worldwide, and made him a global figure in popular culture for over a decade.[4][5] Over the course of his career secondnameplaceholder became known as a Rastafari icon, and he infused his music with a sense of spirituality.[6] He is also considered a global symbol of Jamaican music and culture and identity, and was controversial in his outspoken support for the legalization of marijuana, while he also advocated for Pan-Africanism.[7]\n
 Born in Nine Mile, British Jamaica, secondnameplaceholder began his professional musical career in 1963, after forming firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder and the Wailers. The group released its debut studio album The Wailing Wailers in 1965, which contained the single "One Love/People Get Ready"; the song was popular worldwide, and established the group as a rising figure in reggae.[8] The Wailers subsequently released eleven further studio albums; while initially employing louder instrumentation and singing, the group began engaging in rhythmic-based song construction in the late 1960s and early 1970s, which coincided with the singer's conversion to Rastafari. During this period secondnameplaceholder relocated to London, and the group embodied their musical shift with the release of the album The Best of The Wailers (1971).[9]\n
                                                                                    The group attained international success after the release of the albums Catch a Fire and Burnin' (both 1973), and forged a reputation as touring artists. Following the disbandment of the Wailers a year later, secondnameplaceholder went on to release his solo material under the band's name.[10] His debut studio album Natty Dread (1974) received positive reception, as did its follow-up Rastaman Vibration (1976). A few months after the album's release secondnameplaceholder survived an assassination attempt at his home in Jamaica, which prompted him to permanently relocate to London. During his time in London he recorded the album Exodus (1977); it incorporated elements of blues, soul, and British rock and enjoyed widespread commercial and critical success.\n
                                                                                                             In 1977, secondnameplaceholder was diagnosed with acral lentiginous melanoma; he died as a result of the illness in 1981. His fans around the world expressed their grief, and he received a state funeral in Jamaica. The greatest hits album Legend was released in 1984, and became the best-selling reggae album of all time.[11] secondnameplaceholder also ranks as one of the best-selling music artists of all time, with estimated sales of more than 75 million records worldwide.[12] He was posthumously honored by Jamaica soon after his death with a designated Order of Merit by his nation. In 1994, he was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Rolling Stone ranked him No. 11 on its list of the 100 Greatest Artists of All Time.[13]\n                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder is an American rock band formed in 1983 in Sayreville, New Jersey. It consists of singer Jon firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, keyboardist David Bryan, drummer Tico Torres, guitarist Phil X, and bassist Hugh McDonald.[1] Original bassist Alec John Such quit the band in 1994, and longtime guitarist and co-songwriter Richie Sambora left in 2013.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   In 1984 and 1985, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder released their first two albums and their debut single "Runaway" managed to crack the Top 40. In 1986, the band achieved widespread success and global recognition with their third album, Slippery When Wet, which sold over 20 million copies and included three Top 10 singles, two of which reached No. 1 ("You Give Love a Bad Name" and "Livin' on a Prayer")[2] Their fourth album, New Jersey (1988), was also very successful, selling over 10 million copies and featuring five Top 10 singles (a record for a glam metal, heavy metal and hard rock album), two of which reached No. 1 ("Bad Medicine" and "I'll Be There for You"). After the band toured and recorded extensively during the late 1980s, culminating in the 1988–1990 New Jersey Tour, Jon firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder and Richie Sambora released successful solo albums in 1990 and 1991, respectively.\n
 In 1992, the band returned with the double-platinum Keep the Faith. This was followed by their biggest-selling and longest-charting single "Always" (1994) and the album These Days (1995), which proved to be a bigger success in Europe than in the United States, producing four Top Ten singles in the United Kingdom. Following a second hiatus, their 2000 album Crush, particularly the lead single, "It's My Life", successfully introduced the band to a younger audience. The band followed up with Bounce in 2002.  The platinum albums Have a Nice Day (2005)  and Lost Highway (2007) saw the band incorporate elements of country music into some of the songs, including the 2006 single "Who Says You Can't Go Home", which won the band a Grammy Award and became the first single by a rock band to reach No. 1 on the country charts. The Circle (2009) marked a return to the band's rock sound. The band also enjoyed great success touring, with both the 2005–2006 Have a Nice Day Tour and 2007–2008 Lost Highway Tour ranking among the Top 20 highest-grossing concert tours of the 2000s and the 2013 Because We Can Tour ranking among the highest-grossing of the 2010s. The band continues to tour and record, with their most recent album This House Is Not for Sale and its associated tour encompassing 2016–2019.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder has released 15 studio albums, five compilations and three live albums. They have sold more than 100 million records worldwide, making them one of the best-selling American rock bands,[3][4] and performed more than 2,700 concerts in over 50 countries for more than 34 million fans.[5][6] firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was inducted into the UK Music Hall of Fame in 2006, and into the US Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2018.[7] The band received the Award of Merit at the American Music Awards in 2004,[8] and Jon firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder and Richie Sambora were inducted into Songwriters Hall of Fame in 2009.[9][10]\n                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         firstnameplaceholder Lynn secondnameplaceholder (/reɪt/;[1] born November 8, 1949) is an American blues singer, guitarist, songwriter, and activist.\n
 During the 1970s, secondnameplaceholder released a series of roots-influenced albums that incorporated elements of blues, rock, folk and country. In 1989, after several years of critical acclaim but little commercial success, she had a major hit with the album Nick of Time. The following two albums, Luck of the Draw (1991) and Longing in Their Hearts (1994), were multimillion sellers, generating several hit singles, including "Something to Talk About", "Love Sneakin' Up On You", and the ballad "I Can't Make You Love Me" (with Bruce Hornsby on piano).\n
                                                                                                                        secondnameplaceholder has received 10 Grammy Awards. She is listed as number 50 in Rolling Stone's list of the "100 Greatest Singers of All Time"[2] and number 89 on the magazine's list of the "100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time".[3] Australian country music artist Graeme Connors has said, "firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder does something with a lyric no one else can do; she bends it and twists it right into your heart."[4]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   : Not a Grammy Award, but awarded by The Recording Academy\n                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder (pronounced boys to men) also known as B2M, is an American boy band from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, best known for emotional ballads and a cappella harmonies. They are currently a trio composed of baritone Nathan Morris alongside tenors Wanya Morris and Shawn Stockman. During the 1990s, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder found fame on Motown Records as a quartet including bass Michael McCary, who left the group in 2003 due to scoliosis.[2]\n
 During the 1990s, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder gained international success. This began with the release of top 5 singles "Motownphilly" and \n"It's So Hard to Say Goodbye to Yesterday" in 1991, followed by the number one single "End of the Road" in 1992, which reached the top of charts worldwide.[3] "End of the Road" set a new record for longevity, staying at number one on the Billboard Hot 100 for thirteen weeks. firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder proceeded to break this record with the subsequent releases of "I'll Make Love to You" and "One Sweet Day" (with Mariah Carey), which, at fourteen and sixteen weeks respectively, each set new records for the total number of weeks at number one. "I'll Make Love to You" also topped the charts in Australia (for four weeks) and garnered international success.\n
                                                                              Consequently, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder is among the music industry's elite with regard to time spent at number one in Billboard history with 50 cumulative weeks, ranking fourth behind Elvis Presley, The Beatles, and Carey. Furthermore, when "On Bended Knee" took the number one spot away from "I'll Make Love to You", firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder became only the third artists ever (after The Beatles and Presley) to replace themselves at the top of the Billboard Hot 100.[4] These achievements were enough to earn firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder recognition as Billboard magazine's biggest boy band during the period of 1987 to 2012.[5] firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder has received four Grammy Awards.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder continue to perform worldwide, as a trio. Their most recent studio album, Under the Streetlight, was released in 2017.[6]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       In June 2017, a section of Broad Street (from Christian to Carpenter Streets) in Philadelphia was renamed "firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder Boulevard". This section of the street is near the High School for the Creative and Performing Arts, where the members once attended.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Billboard Music Awards\n\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   Grammy Awards\n\n

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Soul Train Music Awards\n\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Soul Train Music Awards\n\n firstnameplaceholder Keith secondnameplaceholder  (born January 20, 1985) is an American country music singer, songwriter and record producer from Jefferson, Georgia. He was originally signed to Colt Ford's label, Average Joes Entertainment, where he released Modern Day Prodigal Son and Halfway to Heaven. He is now signed to the Valory division of Big Machine Records where he has released four studio albums—a deluxe edition of Halfway to Heaven, Just as I Am, The Devil Don't Sleep, Fire & Brimstone, and 11 country chart entries, four of which have gone to number one. He also co-wrote (with Colt Ford) and originally recorded Jason Aldean's singles "My Kinda Party" and "Dirt Road Anthem."\n firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder (born June 21, 1946) is an American singer and songwriter, who was a recording artist for Motown Records during the 1960s. Her best-known recordings are the soul hits, "Every Little Bit Hurts", "When I'm Gone", and "You've Made Me So Very Happy." The latter, which she co-wrote, was later widely popularized when it became a Top Ten hit for Blood, Sweat & Tears.  She left Motown after four years, at the age of 22, and largely retired from the music industry until the 1990s, after her recordings had become popular on the British "Northern soul" scene.\n                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      firstnameplaceholder Peter George St John le Baptiste de la Salle secondnameplaceholder RDI (/ˈiːnoʊ/; born firstnameplaceholder Peter George secondnameplaceholder; 15 May 1948) is an English musician, composer, record producer, visual artist, and theorist best known for his pioneering work in ambient music and contributions to rock, pop and electronica.[1] A self-described "non-musician", secondnameplaceholder has helped introduce unique conceptual approaches and recording techniques to contemporary music.[1][2] He has been described as one of popular music's most influential and innovative figures.[1][3]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           Born in Suffolk, secondnameplaceholder studied painting and experimental music at the art school of Ipswich Civic College in the mid 1960s, and then at Winchester School of Art. He joined glam rock group Roxy Music as synthesizer player in 1971, recording two albums with the group but departing in 1973 amidst tensions with Roxy frontman Bryan Ferry. secondnameplaceholder went on to record a number of solo albums beginning with Here Come the Warm Jets (1974). In the mid-1970s, he began exploring a minimalist direction on releases such as Discreet Music (1975) and Ambient 1: Music for Airports (1978), coining the term "ambient music" with the latter.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Alongside his solo work, secondnameplaceholder collaborated frequently with other musicians in the 1970s, including Robert Fripp, Harmonia, Cluster, Harold Budd, David Bowie, and David Byrne. He also established himself as a sought-after producer, working on albums by John Cale, Jon Hassell, Laraaji, Talking Heads, Ultravox, and Devo, as well as the no wave compilation No New York (1978). In subsequent decades, secondnameplaceholder continued to record solo albums and produce for other artists, most prominently U2 and Coldplay, alongside work with artists such as Daniel Lanois, Laurie Anderson, Grace Jones, Slowdive, Karl Hyde, James, Kevin Shields, and Damon Albarn.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Dating back to his time as a student, secondnameplaceholder has also worked in other media, including sound installations, film, and writing. In the mid-1970s, he co-developed Oblique Strategies, a deck of cards featuring aphorisms intended to spur creative thinking. From the 1970s onwards, secondnameplaceholder's installations have included the sails of the Sydney Opera House in 2009[4] and the Lovell Telescope at Jodrell Bank in 2016. An advocate of a range of humanitarian causes, secondnameplaceholder writes on a variety of subjects and is a founding member of the Long Now Foundation.[5] In 2019, secondnameplaceholder was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as a member of Roxy Music.[6]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            In 1969, after separating from his wife, secondnameplaceholder moved to London where his professional music career began. He became involved with the Scratch Orchestra and the Portsmouth Sinfonia; secondnameplaceholder's first appearance on a commercially released recording is the Deutsche Grammophon edition of The Great Learning (1971) by Cornelius Cardew and the Scratch Orchestra which features secondnameplaceholder as one of the voices on the track "Paragraph 7".[21] Another early recording was the soundtrack to Berlin Horse (1970), a nine-minute avant-garde art film by Malcolm Le Grice.[22][23] At one point, secondnameplaceholder had to earn money as paste-up assistant for the advertisement section of a local paper for three months. He quit and became an electronics dealer by buying old speakers and making new cabinets for them before selling them to friends.[12]\n
 In 1971, secondnameplaceholder co-formed the glam and art rock band Roxy Music. He had a chance meeting with saxophonist Andy Mackay at a train station, which led to him joining the band. secondnameplaceholder later said: "If I'd walked ten yards further on the platform, or missed that train, or been in the next carriage, I probably would have been an art teacher now".[24] secondnameplaceholder played on their first two albums, Roxy Music (1972) and For Your Pleasure (1973), and is credited as "secondnameplaceholder" with playing the VCS 3 synthesiser, tape effects, backing vocals, and co-producer. Initially secondnameplaceholder did not appear on stage at their live shows, but operated the group's mixing desk at the centre of the concert venue where he had a microphone to sing backup vocals. After the group secured a record deal, secondnameplaceholder joined them on stage performing the synthesiser[12] and became known for his flamboyant costumes and makeup. After touring For Your Pleasure ended in mid-1973, secondnameplaceholder quit the band. He cited disagreements with lead singer Bryan Ferry and the frontman's insistence on being in command of the group, which affected secondnameplaceholder's ability to incorporate his own ideas.[25]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        From the beginning of his solo career in 1973, secondnameplaceholder was in demand as a record producer. The first album with secondnameplaceholder credited as producer was Lucky Leif and the Longships by Robert Calvert. secondnameplaceholder's lengthy string of producer credits includes albums for Talking Heads, U2, Devo, Ultravox and James. He also produced part of the 1993 album When I Was a Boy by Jane Siberry. He won the best producer award at the 1994 and 1996 BRIT Awards.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                secondnameplaceholder describes himself as a "non-musician", using the term "treatments" to describe his modification of the sound of musical instruments, and to separate his role from that of the traditional instrumentalist. His skill at using "The Studio as a Compositional Tool"[64] (the title of an essay by secondnameplaceholder) led in part to his career as a producer.
