   Jon Gordon secondnameplaceholderseth Jr. (born January 29, 1981), known as firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, is an American blues, gospel, and rock singer, songwriter, and guitarist.[1] He has five albums that charted on the top 50 of the Billboard 200 chart and has won a Grammy Award for Turn Around.\n
                                                                                                                  Jon Gordon secondnameplaceholderseth Jr. (born January 29, 1981), known as firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, is an American blues, gospel, and rock singer, songwriter, and guitarist.[1] He has five albums that charted on the top 50 of the Billboard 200 chart and has won a Grammy Award for Turn Around.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           On September 17, 2013, secondnameplaceholder released his first studio album in seven years, Fight for My Soul.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 Signs, was released on September 1, 2017 in Europe, and on September 8, in North America.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        On January 12, 2021, it was announced that all confirmed concert dates are cancelled until further notice, due to a medical issue that affects secondnameplaceholder's singing.[7]\n
 secondnameplaceholder married former Kids Incorporated cast member Haylie Johnson on June 8, 2001, making him the brother-in-law of actress Ashley Johnson. secondnameplaceholder and his wife share the same birthday, although she is one year older. They live in Los Angeles and have five children: son Raimy Lee and daughter Saylor Monroe (fraternal twins), daughter Rennix Belle, daughter Lilou Jaymes, and son Tevi Flynn.[8]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                secondnameplaceholder has two older sisters, Stephanie and Heidi Jo. He also has one younger sister, Jessica ("Jesse"), who was a contestant on season 8 of American Idol.\n
                       secondnameplaceholder became a Christian in 2000.[9][10] In an interview with Sara Groves on Christianity Today, secondnameplaceholder gave details about his conversion, assuring he had a supernatural experience with the Holy Ghost.[10] In his own words, he has said that he formerly "hated Christianity"[11] and "despised the things of God", but now he wants to share with others about Jesus' love.[12]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                 The songs "Only a Man" and "Thankful" from his album Turn Around, are about his belief in God. He has also co-written a couple of songs with Christian-music artist Steven Curtis Chapman, notably "My Love Remains".[13]\n Joscelyn Eve Stoker[6] (born 11 April 1987), better known by her stage name firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, is a British singer, songwriter, and actress. She rose to fame in late 2003 with her multi-platinum debut album, The Soul Sessions, which made the 2004 Mercury Prize shortlist. Her second album, the similarly multi-platinum Mind Body & Soul (2004), topped the UK Albums Chart and spawned the top ten hit "You Had Me", secondnameplaceholder's most successful single on the UK Singles Chart to date. Both the album and single received one nomination at the 2005 Grammy Awards, while secondnameplaceholder herself was nominated for Best New Artist, and in an annual BBC poll of music critics, Sound of 2004,[7] was ranked fifth as a predicted breakthrough act of 2004.[7] She became the youngest British female singer to top the UK Albums Chart. secondnameplaceholder's third album, Introducing firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, released in March 2007, achieved gold record status by the RIAA and yielded the second-ever highest debut for a British female solo artist on the Billboard 200, and became secondnameplaceholder's first top five album in the US.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             She released her fourth album, Colour Me Free!, on 20 October 2009, which reached the top 10 on Billboard. secondnameplaceholder released her fifth album, LP1, on 22 July 2011, which reached the top 10 on Billboard. Throughout her career, secondnameplaceholder has sold 15 million records worldwide, establishing herself as one of the best-selling soul artists of the 2000s, and the best-selling British artists of her time.[8] Her first three albums have sold over 2,722,000 copies in the US, while her first two albums have sold over 2 million copies in the UK.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            secondnameplaceholder has earned several notable accolades including two Brit Awards and one Grammy Award out of five nominations. She also made her film acting debut in 2006 with the fantasy adventure film Eragon, and made her television debut portraying Anne of Cleves in the Showtime series The Tudors in 2009.[9] secondnameplaceholder was the youngest woman on the 2006 Sunday Times Rich List—an annual list of the UK's wealthiest people—with £6 million.[10][11] In 2012, her net worth was estimated to be £10 million, making her the fifth richest British musician under 30.[12] The Soul Sessions Vol. 2 (2012) is her fourth consecutive album to reach the top 10 on the Billboard 200, with Australian producer Cam Noble.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       During her career, secondnameplaceholder won nine awards, including one Grammy Award and two Brit Awards.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       During her career, secondnameplaceholder won nine awards, including one Grammy Award and two Brit Awards.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       During her career, secondnameplaceholder won nine awards, including one Grammy Award and two Brit Awards.\n firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder (née Peck; September 26, 1926 – October 18, 2000) was an American singer and actress whose career spanned more than 40 years. A torch singer noted for her sultry, languid contralto vocals, secondnameplaceholder recorded over thirty albums of pop and jazz standards between 1955 and 1969. Her recording of "Cry Me a River", a track she introduced on her debut album, was inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame in 2001. In addition to her musical notice, secondnameplaceholder was nominated for a Golden Globe Award in 1974 for her portrayal of nurse Dixie McCall in the television series Emergency!.\n
                                                                                                   Born in Santa Rosa, California to vaudevillian parents, secondnameplaceholder was discovered while working as an elevator operator in downtown Los Angeles, and began her career as an actress. secondnameplaceholder's 35-year acting career began in film in 1944, and included roles as the female lead in numerous westerns, co-starring with Rock Hudson in The Fat Man (1951), with Robert Taylor and John Cassavetes in Saddle the Wind (1958), with Gary Cooper in Man of the West (1958) and opposite Robert Mitchum in The Wonderful Country (1959).\n
                                                                                                                                                                                             In the mid-1950s, she signed a recording contract with the newly established Liberty Records, marking the beginning of her professional musical career. She released her final studio album in 1969, but achieved continuing success playing the female starring role of nurse Dixie McCall, in the television series Emergency! (1972–1979), in which she appeared opposite her real-life husband, Bobby Troup. The show was produced by her ex-husband, Jack Webb.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             A shy and introverted woman, secondnameplaceholder rarely granted interviews, and spent the remainder of her life out of the public sphere. In 1995, she suffered a stroke, which left her with permanent health problems. In 1999, she was diagnosed with lung cancer, but forewent treatment due to her already compromised physical state. She died of cardiac arrest the following year in Los Angeles, aged 74.\n firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder is an American alternative hip hop group formed in 1993 by rappers Charles Stewart (Chali 2na), Dante Givens (Akil), Courtenay Henderson (Soup aka Zaakir), Marc Stuart (Marc 7); and disc jockeys Mark Potsic (DJ Nu-Mark) and Lucas Macfadden (Cut Chemist).[1] \nThe six piece crew that was formed, came out of the Los Angeles venue Good Life.[2]\nThe group broke up in 2007,[3]\nshortly after releasing their fourth LP Feedback, citing "musical differences,"[4] but returned to the stage in 2013 and released a new track in 2014.[secondnameplaceholder] The members have continued to release music individually.\n                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             firstnameplaceholder Drew secondnameplaceholder (/biːbər/; born March 1, 1994) is a Canadian singer. He was discovered by American record executive Scooter Braun and signed with RBMG Records in 2008, gaining recognition with the release of his debut EP My World (2009) and soon establishing himself as a teen idol.[4]\n
                   secondnameplaceholder's debut album, My World 2.0 (2010), debuted atop the Billboard 200, making him the youngest solo male act to top the chart in 47 years.[5] The album also contained the internationally successful single "Baby", which became the highest certificated single of all time in the US.[6] His second album, Under the Mistletoe (2011), was the first Christmas album by a male artist to debut at number one on the Billboard 200,[7] while his third album, Believe (2012), saw experimentation with dance-pop and mature themes.[8] Following Believe, secondnameplaceholder's public image went through a drastic change through various controversies and legal issues during 2013 and 2014,[9] leading to Rolling Stone dubbing him "Bad Boy" on their March 2014 issue.[10]\n
 His fourth album, Purpose, was released in 2015. It was preceded by "Where Are Ü Now", a collaboration with Jack Ü, which saw secondnameplaceholder explore EDM,[11] and win the Grammy Award for Best Dance Recording.[12] Purpose produced three number-one singles: "What Do You Mean?", "Love Yourself", and "Sorry". secondnameplaceholder diversified on later collaborations, with "Cold Water", "Let Me Love You", "I'm the One", and "I Don't Care" reaching the top five in the U.S., while his remix to "Despacito" tied the then-record for most weeks atop the Billboard Hot 100, and "10,000 Hours" won the Grammy Award for Best Country Duo/Group Performance.[13] His fifth album, Changes was released in 2020, while his sixth album, Justice (2021), produced the US number-one single "Peaches".[14]\n
                                                                                                                                        Among the world's best-selling music artists, with over 150 million records sold, secondnameplaceholder is credited with three Diamond certifications from the RIAA for "Baby", "Sorry" and "Despacito". He has received numerous accolades, including 22 Guinness World Records, two Grammy Awards, a record 21 MTV Europe Music Awards, 20 Billboard Music Awards, 18 American Music Awards, two Brit Awards, four MTV Video Music Awards, and a Latin Grammy Award.[15] Time named secondnameplaceholder one of the 100 most influential people in the world in 2011, and he was included on Forbes' list of the top ten most powerful celebrities in 2011, 2012, and 2013.[16]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 Outside music, secondnameplaceholder's marriage to Hailey Baldwin has received considerable media attention, and he also starred in the concert films firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder: Never Say Never (2011) and firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's Believe (2013), while his personal issues were chronicled in the documentary series firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder: Seasons (2020).\n                                                                                                                                                                                                           firstnameplaceholder Lee secondnameplaceholder (born August 21, 1988) is an American singer and songwriter. She has won six Grammy Awards (including the Grammy Award for Album of the Year in 2019), seven Country Music Association Awards, and three Academy of Country Music Awards. secondnameplaceholder self-released three solo albums and one more as Texas Two Bits, before appearing on the fifth season of the USA Network's singing competition Nashville Star in 2007, where she placed seventh.[2][3]\n
 She later signed to Mercury Nashville in 2012 and released her critically acclaimed debut album Same Trailer Different Park in 2013. Her debut won the Grammy Award for Best Country Album. The album's lead single "Merry Go 'Round" won her the Grammy Award for Best Country Song. It also featured the platinum certified single "Follow Your Arrow" which won her the Country Music Association Award for Song of the Year. In 2015, she released her second studio album Pageant Material (2015). Her sophomore effort also received critical acclaim and a Best Country Album Grammy nomination.[4][5] secondnameplaceholder also released a Christmas-themed album, A Very firstnameplaceholder Christmas, in 2016.[6]\n
           Her fourth studio album Golden Hour (2018) was released to widespread critical acclaim and won all four of its nominated Grammy Award categories, including Album of the Year and Best Country Album.[7] The album's first two singles, "Butterflies" and "Space Cowboy", won Best Country Solo Performance and Best Country Song, respectively.[8] Golden Hour also won the Academy of Country Music and the Country Music Association Award for Album of the Year, making secondnameplaceholder only the fifth artist to win all three major Album of the Year (Grammy, CMA and ACM) awards for the same album as well as the second artist to win the Grammy, CMA, ACM and all-genre Grammy Album of the Year.[9]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             The Academy of Country Music Awards is an annual country music awards show, the first ever created, established in 1966. secondnameplaceholder has won four times.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            The American Music Awards is an annual major American music award show by the American Broadcasting Company, presented since 1973. \n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      The Americana Music Honors & Awards were established by the Americana Music Association to celebrate the best releases in Americana music\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  The Country Music Association Awards is an annual country music awards show, established in 1967. secondnameplaceholder has won seven awards.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    The CMT Music Awards is an annual ceremony dedicated exclusively to honor country music videos. It was established in 1967.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  The Grammy Awards are presented annually by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences for outstanding achievements in the music industry. It has been presented since 1958. secondnameplaceholder has been nominated nine times and won six awards.\n

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  The Grammy Awards are presented annually by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences for outstanding achievements in the music industry. It has been presented since 1958. secondnameplaceholder has been nominated nine times and won six awards.\n firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder are an English indie rock[1][3] band from Leeds who formed in 2000 as Parva, releasing one studio album, 22, in 2003, before renaming and establishing themselves in their current name that same year. Since their formation the band has consisted of lead vocalist Ricky Barnett-Wilson, guitarist Andrew "Whitey" White, bassist Simon Rix, keyboardist  Nick "Peanut" Baines and since 2013 drummer Vijay Mistry, who replaced founding drummer Nick Hodgson following his departure from the band in late 2012.[4]\n
                                                                Primarily inspired by new wave and punk rock music of the late 1970s and 1980s, the band have released seven original studio albums: Employment (2005), Yours Truly, Angry Mob (2007), Off with Their Heads (2008), The Future Is Medieval (2011), Education, Education, Education & War (2014),  Stay Together (2016), and Duck (2019), one EP: Lap of Honour (2005), one compilation album: Souvenir: The Singles 2004–2012 (2012) and numerous singles, including the number one hit song "Ruby".\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Their album Employment enjoyed critical and commercial success with over three million copies sold.[5] It has won the band three Brit Awards, including the award for Best British Group,[6] a NME award for Best Album,[7] and was shortlisted for the Mercury Prize.[8][9]\n
                                                                           Their UK hit singles include 2004 and 2005 number 9 hit "I Predict a Riot", 2007 UK number 1 hit "Ruby", which has sold over 461,000 copies,[10] from their platinum album Yours Truly, Angry Mob plus a further two Top 20 singles in 2007 with "The Angry Mob" and "Everything Is Average Nowadays". Their singles "Ruby", "I Predict a Riot", "Everyday I Love You Less and Less", "Never Miss a Beat" and "Oh My God" had sold a combined total of 1.1 million up to August 2012.[10]\n

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Silver Clef Awards\n\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          TMF Awards\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               UK Music Video Awards\n

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               UK Music Video Awards\n                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               firstnameplaceholder Omari secondnameplaceholder (/ˈkɑːnjeɪ/; born June 8, 1977) is an American rapper, singer, record producer, businessman, politician, and fashion designer.[3][4][5] He has been influential in the 21st-century development of mainstream hip hop, popular music, and popular culture in general.[6]\n
 Born in Atlanta and raised in Chicago, secondnameplaceholder gained notoriety as a producer for Roc-A-Fella Records in the early 2000s, producing singles for several mainstream artists. Intent on pursuing a solo career as a rapper, secondnameplaceholder released his debut album The College Dropout in 2004 to critical and commercial success, and founded the record label GOOD Music. He experimented with a variety of musical genres on subsequent acclaimed studio albums, including Late Registration (2005), Graduation (2007), and 808s & Heartbreak (2008). Drawing inspiration from maximalism and minimalism, respectively, secondnameplaceholder's fifth album My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy (2010) and sixth album Yeezus (2013) were also critical successes. He went on to release The Life of Pablo (2016), Ye (2018), and Jesus Is King (2019). secondnameplaceholder's discography also includes the full-length collaborations Watch the Throne (2011) and Kids See Ghosts (2018) with Jay-Z and Kid Cudi, respectively.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                       secondnameplaceholder's outspoken views and life outside of music have received significant media attention. He has been a frequent source of controversy for his conduct at award shows, on social media, and in other public settings, as well as for his comments on the music and fashion industries, U.S. politics, and race. In 2020, he ran an independent presidential campaign that advocated for a consistent life ethic.[7][8] His Christian faith, as well as his marriage to television personality Kim Kardashian, have also been a source of media attention.[9][10] As a fashion designer, he has collaborated with Nike, Louis Vuitton, and A.P.C. on both clothing and footwear, and have most prominently resulted in the Yeezy collaboration with Adidas beginning in 2013. He is the founder and head of the creative content company DONDA.\n
                                                                                                                                                           secondnameplaceholder is one of the world's best-selling music artists, with more than 20 million albums and 140 million singles sold worldwide. He has won a total of 22 Grammy Awards, making him one of the most awarded artists of all time.[11][12] Among his other awards are the Billboard Artist Achievement Award, a joint-record three Brit Awards for Best International Male Solo Artist and the Michael Jackson Video Vanguard Award.[13] Six of his albums were included on Rolling Stone's 2020 500 Greatest Albums of All Time list; the same publication named him one of the 100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time.[14] secondnameplaceholder is the tied holder for the most albums (four) topping the annual Pazz & Jop critic poll, a distinction he shares with Bob Dylan. Time magazine named him one of the 100 most influential people in the world in 2005 and 2015.\n                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Catherine secondnameplaceholder CBE (born 30 July 1958) is an English singer, songwriter, musician, dancer and record producer. In 1978, aged 19, she topped the UK Singles Chart for four weeks with her debut single "Wuthering Heights", becoming the first female artist to achieve a UK number one with a self-written song.[10] secondnameplaceholder has since released 25 UK Top 40 singles, including the Top 10 hits "The Man with the Child in His Eyes", "Babooshka", "Running Up That Hill", "Don't Give Up" (a duet with Peter Gabriel), and "King of the Mountain". All 10 of her studio albums reached the UK Top 10, including the UK number one albums Never for Ever (1980), Hounds of Love (1985), and the compilation The Whole Story (1986). She was the first British solo female artist to top the UK album charts and the first female artist to enter the album chart at number one.[11]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 secondnameplaceholder began writing songs at 11. She was signed to EMI Records after Pink Floyd guitarist David Gilmour helped produce a demo tape. Her debut album, The Kick Inside, was released in 1978. secondnameplaceholder slowly gained artistic independence in album production and has produced all her studio albums since The Dreaming (1982). She took a hiatus between her seventh and eighth albums, The Red Shoes (1993) and Aerial (2005). secondnameplaceholder drew attention again in 2014 with her concert residency Before the Dawn, her first shows since 1979's The Tour of Life.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        secondnameplaceholder's eclectic and experimental musical style, unconventional lyrics, and literary themes have influenced a diverse range of artists. She has been nominated for 13 British Phonographic Industry accolades,[12] winning for Best British Female Artist in 1987,[13] and has been nominated for three Grammy Awards. In 2002, secondnameplaceholder was recognised with an Ivor Novello Award for Outstanding Contribution to British Music. secondnameplaceholder was appointed a CBE in the 2013 New Year Honours for services to music.[14][15] She was nominated twice for induction in the 2018 and 2021 Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.[16][17]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      For her debut album, The Kick Inside (1978), secondnameplaceholder was persuaded to use established session musicians instead of the KT secondnameplaceholder Band. She retained some of these even after she had brought her bandmates back on board.[39] Her brother Paddy played the harmonica and mandolin. Stuart Elliott played some of the drums and became her main drummer on subsequent albums.[40] The Kick Inside was released when secondnameplaceholder was 19, with some songs written when she was as young as 13. EMI originally wanted the more rock-oriented track "James and the Cold Gun" to be her debut single, but secondnameplaceholder, who already had a reputation for asserting herself in decisions about her work, insisted that it should be "Wuthering Heights".[26]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               In the United Kingdom alone, The Kick Inside sold over a million copies.[41] "Wuthering Heights" topped the UK and Australian charts and became an international hit.[42] secondnameplaceholder became the first British woman to reach number one on the UK charts with a self-written song.[43] "The Man with the Child in His Eyes" made it onto the American Billboard Hot 100 where it reached number 85 in early 1979, and went on to win her an Ivor Novello Award in 1979 for Outstanding British Lyric.[44] According to Guinness World Records, secondnameplaceholder was the first female artist in pop history to have written every track on a million-selling debut album.[41]\n
                                                                                                                                                          Bob Mercer blamed secondnameplaceholder's lesser success in the United States on American radio formats, saying there were no outlets for secondnameplaceholder's visual presentation.[33] EMI capitalised on secondnameplaceholder's appearance by promoting the album with a poster of her in a tight pink top that emphasised her breasts. In an interview with NME in 1982, secondnameplaceholder criticised the choice: "People weren't even generally aware that I wrote my own songs or played the piano. The media just promoted me as a female body. It's like I've had to prove that I'm an artist in a female body."[26] In late 1978, EMI persuaded secondnameplaceholder to quickly record a follow-up album, Lionheart, to take advantage of the success of The Kick Inside. The album was produced by Andrew Powell, assisted by secondnameplaceholder. While it gained high sales and spawned the hit single "Wow", it did not reach the success of The Kick Inside, reaching number six in the UK album charts. She went on to express dissatisfaction with Lionheart, feeling that it had needed more time.[45]\n
                                                                              secondnameplaceholder set up her own publishing company, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder Music, and her own management company, Novercia, to maintain control of her work. Members of her family, along with secondnameplaceholder herself, composed the board of directors.[26] Following the release of Lionheart, she was required by EMI to undertake heavy promotional work and an exhausting tour.[46] The Tour of Life began in April 1979 and lasted six weeks. It was described by The Guardian as "an extraordinary, hydra-headed beast, combining music, dance, poetry, mime, burlesque, magic and theatre".[10] The show was co-devised and performed on stage with magician Simon Drake.[47] secondnameplaceholder was involved in every aspect of the production, choreography, set design, costume design and hiring.[26] The shows were noted for her dancing, complex lighting and her 17 costume changes per show. Because of her need to dance as she sang, sound engineers used a wire coat hanger and a radio microphone to fashion a headset microphone; it was the first used by a rock performer since the Spotnicks used a rudimentary version in the early 1960s.[1][48]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 Released in September 1980, Never for Ever saw secondnameplaceholder's second foray into production, co-producing with Jon Kelly. Her first experience as a producer was on her Live on Stage EP, released after her tour the previous year. The first two albums had resulted in a definitive sound evident in every track, with orchestral arrangements supporting the live band sound. The range of styles on Never for Ever is much more diverse, veering from the straightforward rocker "Violin" to the wistful waltz of hit single "Army Dreamers".\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 Hounds of Love was released in 1985. Because of the high cost of hiring studio space for her previous album, she built a private studio near her home, where she could work at her own pace.[60] Hounds of Love ultimately topped the charts in the UK, knocking Madonna's Like a Virgin from the number-one position.[61]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    The album takes advantage of the vinyl and cassette formats with two very different sides. The first side, Hounds of Love, contains five "accessible" pop songs, including the four singles "Running Up that Hill", "Cloudbusting", "Hounds of Love", and "The Big Sky". "Running Up that Hill" reached number three in the UK charts and re-introduced secondnameplaceholder to American listeners, climbing to number 30 on the Billboard Hot 100 in November 1985. The second side of the album, The Ninth Wave, takes its name from Tennyson's poem, "Idylls of the King", about the legendary King Arthur's reign, and is seven interconnecting songs joined in one continuous piece of music.[62]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The album earned secondnameplaceholder nominations for Best Female Solo Artist, Best Album, Best Single, and Best Producer at the 1986 BRIT Awards. In the same year, secondnameplaceholder and Peter Gabriel had a UK Top 10 hit with the duet "Don't Give Up" (Dolly Parton, Gabriel's original choice to sing the female vocal, turned his offer down),[63] and EMI released her "greatest hits" album, The Whole Story. secondnameplaceholder provided a new lead vocal and refreshed backing track on "Wuthering Heights", and recorded a new single, "Experiment IV", for inclusion on the compilation. Dawn French and Hugh Laurie were among those featured in the video for Experiment IV. At the 1987 BRIT Awards, secondnameplaceholder won the award for Best Female Solo Artist.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Released in 1989, The Sensual World was described by secondnameplaceholder herself as "her most honest, personal album".[64] One of the tracks, "Heads We're Dancing", inspired by her own black humour, is about a woman who dances all night with a charming stranger only to discover in the morning that he is Adolf Hitler. The title track drew its inspiration from James Joyce's novel Ulysses.[65] The Sensual World went on to become her biggest-selling album in the US, receiving an RIAA Gold certification four years after its release for 500,000 copies sold. In the United Kingdom album charts, it reached the number-two position.[66] Another single from the album, "This Woman's Work", was featured in the John Hughes film She's Having a Baby, and a slightly remixed version appeared on secondnameplaceholder's album The Sensual World.[67] The song reached number-eight in 2005 on the UK download chart after featuring in a British television advertisement for the charity NSPCC.[68]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    secondnameplaceholder provided vocals on two of Peter Gabriel's albums, including the hits "Games Without Frontiers" and "Don't Give Up", as well as "No Self-Control". Gabriel appeared on secondnameplaceholder's 1979 television special, where they sang a duet of Roy Harper's "Another Day". She has sung on two Roy Harper tracks, "You", on his 1979 album, "The Unknown Soldier"; and "Once", the title track of his 1990 album. She has also sung on the title song of the 1986 Big Country album The Seer; the Midge Ure song "Sister and Brother" from his 1988 album Answers to Nothing; Go West's 1987 single "The King Is Dead"; and two songs with Prince – "Why Should I Love You?", from her 1993 album The Red Shoes, and "My Computer" from Prince's 1996 album Emancipation. In 1987, she sang a verse on the Beatles cover charity single "Let It Be" by Ferry Aid. She sang a line on the charity single "Spirit of the Forest" by Spirit of the Forest in 1989.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         In 1990 secondnameplaceholder produced a song for another artist, Alan Stivell's "Kimiad" for his album Again; this is the only time she has done this to date. Stivell had appeared on The Sensual World. In 1991, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder was invited to perform a cover of Elton John's 1972 song "Rocket Man" for the tribute album Two Rooms: Celebrating the Songs of Elton John & Bernie Taupin. In 2011, Elton John collaborated with secondnameplaceholder once again in "Snowed in at Wheeler Street" for her most recent album 50 Words for Snow. In 1994, secondnameplaceholder covered George Gershwin's "The Man I Love" for the tribute album The Glory of Gershwin. In 1996, secondnameplaceholder contributed a version of "Mná na hÉireann" (Irish for "Women of Ireland") for the Anglo-Irish folk-rock compilation project Common Ground: The Voices of Modern Irish Music. secondnameplaceholder had to sing the song in Irish, which she learned to do phonetically.[211]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 Artists who have contributed to secondnameplaceholder's own albums include Elton John, Eric Clapton, Jeff Beck, David Gilmour, Nigel Kennedy, Gary Brooker, Danny Thompson, and Prince. secondnameplaceholder provided backing vocals for a song that was recorded during the 1990s titled Wouldn't Change a Thing by Lionel Azulay, the drummer with the original band that was later to become the KT secondnameplaceholder Band. The song, which was engineered and produced by Del Palmer, was released on Azulay's album Out of the Ashes.[212] secondnameplaceholder declined a request by Erasure to produce one of their albums because, according to Vince Clarke, "she didn't feel that that was her area".[213]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   secondnameplaceholder was in a long-term relationship with bassist and engineer Del Palmer from the late 1970s to the early 1990s.[214] She is married to guitarist Danny McIntosh.[215]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         secondnameplaceholder is a former resident of Eltham, southeast London.[216] In the 1990s she moved to a canalside residence in Sulhamstead, Berkshire, and then to Devon in 2004.[82] secondnameplaceholder is a vegetarian.[217][218] Raised a Roman Catholic, she said in 1999:\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       The length of time between albums has led to rumours concerning secondnameplaceholder's health or appearance.[141][219] In 2011, she told BBC Radio 4 that the amount of time between albums was stressful: "It's very frustrating the albums take as long as they do ... I wish there weren't such big gaps between them". In the same interview, she denied that she was a perfectionist, saying: "I think it's important that things are flawed ... That's what makes a piece of art interesting sometimes – the bit that's wrong or the mistake you've made that's led onto an idea you wouldn't have had otherwise." She reiterated her prioritisation of her family life.[129]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           secondnameplaceholder's son Bertie (Albert McIntosh), featured prominently in the 2014 concert Before the Dawn. Her nephew, Raven secondnameplaceholder, is violinist in the English indie band Syd Arthur.[220]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    During the 1979 United Kingdom general election campaign, secondnameplaceholder, who at the time was on a live concert tour of the UK, posed for a photograph alongside the Labour Prime Minister James Callaghan.[221]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    In the Comic Strip Presents episode GLC: The Carnage Continues..., she produced and sang on the theme song "Ken". The song is a satirical song about how Hollywood glamourises and fictionalises political figures, in this particular case Ken Livingstone, the former leader of the Greater London Council.[222][223]\n
 In 2016, Canadian news magazine Maclean's published an interview in which secondnameplaceholder was asked about the role of misogyny in the defeat of Hillary Clinton in the 2016 United States presidential election. secondnameplaceholder pointed out that the UK, unlike the US, did have a female premier, Theresa May, who a few months earlier had become the Conservative Prime Minister of the United Kingdom. It quoted secondnameplaceholder as saying: "I actually really like her and think she's wonderful. I think it's the best thing that's happened to us in a long time ... It is great to have a woman in charge of the country. She's very sensible and I think that's a good thing at this point in time."[224] In 2019, secondnameplaceholder published a clarifying statement on her website saying she did not support the Conservative Party. She wrote: "Over the years, I have avoided making political comments in interviews. My response to the interviewer was not meant to be political but rather was in the defence of women in power ... I said that we had a woman in charge of our country, and that I felt it was a good thing to have women in power … it could make it seem like I am a Tory supporter which I want to make clear I am not".[224]\n                                                           Katheryn Elizabeth Hudson (born October 25, 1984), known professionally as firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder, is an American singer, songwriter, and television judge. After singing in church during her childhood, she pursued a career in gospel music as a teenager. secondnameplaceholder signed with Red Hill Records and released her debut studio album firstnameplaceholder Hudson under her birth name in 2001, which was commercially unsuccessful. She moved to Los Angeles the following year to venture into secular music after Red Hill ceased operations and she subsequently began working with producers Glen Ballard, Dr. Luke, and Max Martin. After adopting the stage name 'firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder' (from her mother's maiden name) and being dropped by The Island Def Jam Music Group and Columbia Records, she signed a recording contract with Capitol Records in April 2007.\n
 secondnameplaceholder rose to fame in 2008 with her second album, One of the Boys, a pop rock record containing the controversial U.S number one song "I Kissed a Girl" and "Hot n Cold". Three subsequent albums have topped the U.S. Billboard 200. The disco-influenced Teenage Dream (2010) spawned five chart-topping U.S. Billboard Hot 100 singles–"California Gurls", "Teenage Dream", "Firework", "E.T.", and "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)" — a record tying her with Michael Jackson's Bad. Its follow-up record Prism (2013) was inspired by her divorce, and incorporates pop and dance along with themes of self-reflection, everyday life, and relationships. With the music videos for its chart-topping songs "Roar" and "Dark Horse", secondnameplaceholder became the first artist to have multiple videos reach one billion views on Vevo. 2017's electropop Witness featured a political subtext and a theme of liberation. Her sixth studio album Smile followed in 2020.\n
                                                                                  secondnameplaceholder has nine U.S. Billboard Hot 100 number one singles and has received various awards, including four Guinness World Records, five Billboard Music Awards, five American Music Awards, a Brit Award, and a Juno Award. She has been included in the annual Forbes lists of highest-earning women in music from 2011 to 2019. Her estimated net worth as of 2016 is $125 million. secondnameplaceholder is one of the world's best-selling music artists, having sold over 18 million albums and 125 million singles worldwide. In film, she released an autobiographical documentary titled firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder: Part of Me in 2012, and voiced Smurfette in the 2011 film The Smurfs and its sequel in 2013. Her Super Bowl halftime show performance is the most watched in history. secondnameplaceholder also began serving as a judge on American Idol in 2018.\n                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder (born May 8, 1945) is an American jazz and classical music pianist and composer.[1]\n
 secondnameplaceholder started his career with Art Blakey, moving on to play with Charles Lloyd and Miles Davis. Since the early 1970s he has enjoyed a great deal of success as a group leader and a solo performer in jazz, jazz fusion, and classical music. His improvisations draw from the traditions of jazz and other genres, especially Western classical music, gospel, blues, and ethnic folk music.\n
                                                                                                                     In 2003 secondnameplaceholder received the Polar Music Prize, the first recipient of both the contemporary and classical musician prizes,[2] and in 2004 he received the Léonie Sonning Music Prize. His album The Köln Concert (1975) became the best-selling piano recording in history.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   In 2008 he was inducted into the Down Beat Jazz Hall of Fame in the magazine's 73rd Annual Readers' Poll.[3]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                      secondnameplaceholder has been unable to perform since suffering a stroke in February 2018, and a second stroke in May 2018, which left him partially paralyzed and unable to play with his left hand.[4]\n                                     firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder (born 18 December 1943),[1] often referred to during the 1960s and 1970s as firstnameplaceholder Richard, is an English musician, singer, and songwriter. He is best known as the co-founder, guitarist, secondary vocalist, and co-principal songwriter of the Rolling Stones. Rolling Stone magazine called secondnameplaceholder the creator of "rock's greatest single body of riffs" on guitar and ranked him fourth on its list of 100 best guitarists in 2011. The magazine lists fourteen songs that secondnameplaceholder wrote with the Rolling Stones' lead vocalist Mick Jagger on its "Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time" list.\n
 secondnameplaceholder plays both lead and rhythm guitar parts, often in the same song; the Stones are generally known for their guitar interplay of rhythm and lead ("weaving") between him and the other guitarist in the band – Brian Jones (1962–1969), Mick Taylor (1969–1975), or Ronnie Wood (1975–present). In the recording studio secondnameplaceholder sometimes plays all of the guitar parts, notably on the songs "Paint It Black", "Ruby Tuesday", "Sympathy for the Devil", and "Gimme Shelter". He is also a vocalist, singing backing vocals on many Rolling Stones songs as well as occasional lead vocals, such as on the Rolling Stones' 1972 single "Happy", as well as with his side project, the X-Pensive Winos.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   He has also appeared in three Pirates of the Caribbean films as Captain Teague, father of Jack Sparrow, whose look and characterization was inspired by secondnameplaceholder himself.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           Below is a list of the officially released Rolling Stones tracks on which secondnameplaceholder sings lead vocals or shares lead-vocal duties:\n
