                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   In 1976, secondnameplaceholder was nominated for a Golden Globe Award for "Best Acting Debut in a Motion Picture" for his starring role in the film version of the Who's rock opera Tommy. He also performed as a guest on the Chieftains' recording of Irish Evening: Live at the Grand Opera House which won a Grammy Award for Best Traditional Folk Album in 1993. With the Who, secondnameplaceholder received a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award in 2001 for outstanding artistic significance in music.[75]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           In 1990, secondnameplaceholder was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland, Ohio as a member of the Who.[76] The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame also included three songs that secondnameplaceholder recorded with the Who on the list of 500 Songs that Shaped Rock and Roll, including: "My Generation", "Go to the Mirror!", and "Baba O'Riley".[77] In 2005, secondnameplaceholder received a British Academy of Songwriters, Composers and Authors Gold Badge Award for special and lasting contributions to the British entertainment industry.[78][79]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              In 2003, secondnameplaceholder was honoured by Time magazine as a European Hero for his work with the Teenage Cancer Trust and other charities.[80] In the New Year's Honours List published on 31 December 2004, he was appointed a Commander of the Order of the British Empire for services to Music, the Entertainment Industry and Charity.[81][82]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   As a member of the Who, secondnameplaceholder was inducted in 2005 into the UK Music Hall of Fame.[83] In December 2008, he and Pete Townshend were honoured with America's most prestigious cultural awards as recipients of the 31st annual Kennedy Center Honors in Washington, D.C. by then-President of the United States, George W. Bush.[84] On 4 March 2009, three days after his 65th birthday, secondnameplaceholder accepted the James Joyce Award from the Literary and Historical Society of University College Dublin for outstanding success in the music field.[85]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         On 12 March 2011, he received the Steiger Award (Germany) for excellence in music.[86] In November 2011, secondnameplaceholder and Pete Townshend received the Classic Album Award for Quadrophenia from the Classic Rock Roll of Honour Awards at the Roundhouse in London.[citation needed]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           In July 2012, secondnameplaceholder received an honorary degree from Middlesex University in recognition of his contributions to music.[87]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            secondnameplaceholder has received numerous awards for his music, including Best Blues Album in the British Blues Awards 2015 alongside Wilko Johnson.[88]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               In 2019, secondnameplaceholder was the recipient of the Golden Plate Award of the American Academy of Achievement. He received his Golden Plate along with Pete Townshend and presented by Awards Council member Peter Gabriel.[89][90]\n

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Ronald Frederick secondnameplaceholder (1 April 1946 – 4 June 1997)[1] was an English musician, songwriter, and producer who is best known as the bass guitarist and founding member of two prominent English rock and roll bands: Small Faces (1965–69) and subsequently Faces (1969–73). With Small Faces he was nicknamed "Plonk". After their breakup and re-formation as Faces, he acquired the nickname "Three-Piece".\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           In 1973, secondnameplaceholder quit Faces. Subsequently, he collaborated with other musicians, leading his own bands and pursuing a solo career, while remaining close to his former bandmates. In 1977, he was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. He was supported by charity projects and financial contributions from friends, former bandmates and fans. After living with the disease for 21 years, he died in June 1997, aged 51.[1]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             For his work in both Small Faces and Faces, secondnameplaceholder was inducted posthumously into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2012.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             He has 2 children and 2 step children that take his name, Reuben, Luke, Alana and Sonny.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Ronald Frederick secondnameplaceholder (1 April 1946 – 4 June 1997)[1] was an English musician, songwriter, and producer who is best known as the bass guitarist and founding member of two prominent English rock and roll bands: Small Faces (1965–69) and subsequently Faces (1969–73). With Small Faces he was nicknamed "Plonk". After their breakup and re-formation as Faces, he acquired the nickname "Three-Piece".\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           In 1973, secondnameplaceholder quit Faces. Subsequently, he collaborated with other musicians, leading his own bands and pursuing a solo career, while remaining close to his former bandmates. In 1977, he was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. He was supported by charity projects and financial contributions from friends, former bandmates and fans. After living with the disease for 21 years, he died in June 1997, aged 51.[1]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             For his work in both Small Faces and Faces, secondnameplaceholder was inducted posthumously into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2012.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             He has 2 children and 2 step children that take his name, Reuben, Luke, Alana and Sonny.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           The Small Faces consisted of secondnameplaceholder on bass guitar, Marriott as guitarist and lead vocalist, Jones as drummer, and Winston on keyboards. (The name "Small" was chosen as they were all under 5'5" in height.) They made their debut in 1965, with Ian McLagan replacing Winston in November 1965. They had a successful chart career; secondnameplaceholder and Marriott wrote hit singles consistently, including "Itchycoo Park" and "All or Nothing". At least a dozen successful songs credit secondnameplaceholder,[3] and he co-wrote all but one of the tracks on their 1968 concept album Ogdens' Nut Gone Flake. The album stayed at number one on the UK Albums Chart for six weeks.[4] When Marriott left the group in 1969, they disbanded; they reformed in the late 1970s, but without secondnameplaceholder.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       secondnameplaceholder formed the Faces with McLagan, Jones, firstnameplaceholder Wood and Rod Stewart in 1969. He shared primary songwriting duties with Stewart and Wood, composing or co-composing many of their best-loved pieces. By 1972, with the band's frontman Stewart focusing on his own solo career, secondnameplaceholder took a central role during the recording of their fourth and final album, Ooh La La. Unhappy due to poor reviews of the album and Stewart's lack of commitment, secondnameplaceholder quit[5] in 1973, making his last appearance on 4 June at the Sundown Theatre in Edmonton, London. He was replaced by Tetsu Yamauchi but tellingly the group made no further studio albums following secondnameplaceholder's departure, and split in 1975. According to McLagan, secondnameplaceholder would later regret leaving the Faces.[6] "Debris was one of his more famous vocalist songs.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           In 1973, secondnameplaceholder moved to Fishpool Farm in the village of Hyssington, Montgomeryshire, Wales, just over the border from England. In the late 1970s, already beginning to feel the effects of MS, he moved back to London.[7]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               After leaving the Faces, secondnameplaceholder formed his own band, Slim Chance, who recorded the singles "How Come" (UK No. 11) and "The Poacher" (UK No. 36) and the album Anymore for Anymore, showcasing a blend of British rock, folk and country music. The original line-up of this band included Scottish singer-songwriters Benny Gallagher and Graham Lyle, who provided harmony vocals and played a variety of instruments including keyboards, accordion, acoustic guitar, mandolin, banjo and harmonica. They left in May 1974 to continue their career as a duo, though they would appear on 1977's Rough Mix as guests.\n
 After initial success he toured the UK with "The Passing Show", a circus-type carnival complete with tents and barkers. Viv Stanshall, from the Bonzo Dog Doo Dah Band, served briefly as ringmaster (of sorts). Gallagher & Lyle were replaced with Scottish duo Lucas & McCulloch who provided accordion, mandolin, guitars and banjo. They also acted as support act along with fiddle player Kenny Slaven (who multi tracked all the string parts on "The Poacher." secondnameplaceholder moved to Island Records and issued firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's Slim Chance and One for the Road. In late 1976 he joined a short-lived reformation of Small Faces but quit after two rehearsals, to be replaced by Rick Wills (who later played alongside former Small Faces drummer Kenney Jones in the Jones Gang). However, secondnameplaceholder had signed a contract with Atlantic Records as part of the Small Faces, and was informed that he owed the company an album. His ensuing album with Pete Townshend, Rough Mix, produced by Glyn Johns, which was released in 1977, was lauded as contender for best album of the year by many critics, but the label did not promote it and sales were lacklustre.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 During the recording of Rough Mix, secondnameplaceholder's multiple sclerosis was diagnosed. Nonetheless he toured, wrote and recorded (with Eric Clapton among others) and in 1979 released another album, See Me, which features several songs written by secondnameplaceholder and Clapton. Around this time secondnameplaceholder travelled the highways and byways of England and lived a 'passing show' modern nomadic life in full Gypsy traveller costume and accommodation.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 In 1983 his girlfriend Boo Oldfield contacted Glyn Johns with a view to organising a concert to help fund Action for Research into Multiple Sclerosis. Johns was already arranging Clapton's Command Performance[clarification needed] for Prince Charles so they decided to book the Royal Albert Hall for a further two nights and host a benefit concert.[1] The resulting ARMS Charity Concerts. featured Eric Clapton, Jimmy Page, Jeff Beck, Bill Wyman, Charlie Watts, firstnameplaceholder Wood, Kenney Jones, Andy Fairweather Low, Steve Winwood, Ray Cooper, James Hooker, Fernando Saunders, Chris Stainton, Tony Hymas, Simon Phillips and others. With the addition of Joe Cocker and Paul Rodgers they toured the US.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    secondnameplaceholder emigrated to Texas, USA, in 1984 (first to Houston, then Austin), where the climate was more beneficial to his health and he continued playing, writing, and recording. He formed an American version of Slim Chance, which was, as always, a loose-knit conglomeration of available musicians. For much of the time, membership included Alejandro Escovedo. For close to a decade secondnameplaceholder enjoyed "rock royalty" status in the Austin area. He toured Japan but his health continued to decline. His last performance was in 1992 at a firstnameplaceholder Wood gig alongside Ian McLagan.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 In 1994 firstnameplaceholder and his wife Susan moved to the small town of Trinidad, Colorado. Jimmy Page, Rod Stewart and firstnameplaceholder Wood funded his medical care as no royalties from the Small Faces work were forthcoming - until Kenney Jones and Ian McLagan were eventually able to secure payments, by which time Steve Marriott had died in a house fire and secondnameplaceholder had also died.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       secondnameplaceholder succumbed to pneumonia, in the final stages of his progressive multiple sclerosis, on 4 June 1997 and was buried in the Masonic Cemetery in Trinidad, Colorado.[8] An album of live BBC recordings was about to be released to raise money for his care when secondnameplaceholder died.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           In 1973, secondnameplaceholder moved to Fishpool Farm in the village of Hyssington, Montgomeryshire, Wales, just over the border from England. In the late 1970s, already beginning to feel the effects of MS, he moved back to London.[7]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               After leaving the Faces, secondnameplaceholder formed his own band, Slim Chance, who recorded the singles "How Come" (UK No. 11) and "The Poacher" (UK No. 36) and the album Anymore for Anymore, showcasing a blend of British rock, folk and country music. The original line-up of this band included Scottish singer-songwriters Benny Gallagher and Graham Lyle, who provided harmony vocals and played a variety of instruments including keyboards, accordion, acoustic guitar, mandolin, banjo and harmonica. They left in May 1974 to continue their career as a duo, though they would appear on 1977's Rough Mix as guests.\n

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 In 1983 his girlfriend Boo Oldfield contacted Glyn Johns with a view to organising a concert to help fund Action for Research into Multiple Sclerosis. Johns was already arranging Clapton's Command Performance[clarification needed] for Prince Charles so they decided to book the Royal Albert Hall for a further two nights and host a benefit concert.[1] The resulting ARMS Charity Concerts. featured Eric Clapton, Jimmy Page, Jeff Beck, Bill Wyman, Charlie Watts, firstnameplaceholder Wood, Kenney Jones, Andy Fairweather Low, Steve Winwood, Ray Cooper, James Hooker, Fernando Saunders, Chris Stainton, Tony Hymas, Simon Phillips and others. With the addition of Joe Cocker and Paul Rodgers they toured the US.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    secondnameplaceholder emigrated to Texas, USA, in 1984 (first to Houston, then Austin), where the climate was more beneficial to his health and he continued playing, writing, and recording.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  In 1994 firstnameplaceholder and his wife Susan moved to the small town of Trinidad, Colorado. Jimmy Page, Rod Stewart and firstnameplaceholder Wood funded his medical care as no royalties from the Small Faces work were forthcoming - until Kenney Jones and Ian McLagan were eventually able to secure payments, by which time Steve Marriott had died in a house fire and secondnameplaceholder had also died.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       secondnameplaceholder succumbed to pneumonia, in the final stages of his progressive multiple sclerosis, on 4 June 1997 and was buried in the Masonic Cemetery in Trinidad, Colorado.[8] An album of live BBC recordings was about to be released to raise money for his care when secondnameplaceholder died.\n                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Ronald David secondnameplaceholder (born 1 June 1947)[1] is an English rock musician, songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, artist, author, and radio personality best known as a member of The Rolling Stones since 1975, as well as a member of Faces and the Jeff Beck Group.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              secondnameplaceholder began his career in 1964, when he joined The Birds (not to be confused with the American band The Byrds) on guitar.[2] He then joined the mod group The Creation, but remained with the group only for a short time and appeared on only a few of their singles. He joined the Jeff Beck Group in 1967 as a bass player. Their two albums, Truth and Beck-Ola, are both highly praised.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         The group split in 1969 and secondnameplaceholder departed along with lead vocalist Rod Stewart to join former Small Faces members firstnameplaceholder Lane, Ian McLagan, and Kenney Jones in a new group named Faces. The group found great success in the UK and mainland Europe, though achieved only cult status in the US. secondnameplaceholder sang and co-wrote the popular title track from their final LP, Ooh La La, released in 1973.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                 As the group began to split he began several solo projects, eventually recording his first solo LP, I've Got My Own Album to Do, in 1974. The album featured bandmate McLagan as well as former Beatle George Harrison and Keith Richards of the Rolling Stones, a longtime friend of secondnameplaceholder. After the departure of Mick Taylor from The Stones, Richards soon invited secondnameplaceholder to join them; he did so in 1975, but was not officially inducted as a member until bassist Bill Wyman's departure in 1993.[2]\n
 Besides I've Got My Own Album to Do, secondnameplaceholder has recorded several other solo efforts. Now Look was released in 1975, and peaked at No. 118 on Billboard; he also collaborated with firstnameplaceholder Lane for the soundtrack album Mahoney's Last Stand. secondnameplaceholder also released Gimme Some Neck in 1979, which hit No. 45 in the US; 1234 was released in 1981, peaking at No. 164. He released Slide on This in 1992, Not for Beginners came out in 2002.[2] and I Feel Like Playing in 2010. As a member of The Rolling Stones, secondnameplaceholder was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1989, and was inducted a second time, as a member of Faces, in April 2012.[3][4]\n William firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder (/ˈrɔːri ˈɡæləhər/ GAL-ə-hər; 2 March 1948 – 14 June 1995)[1][2] was an Irish blues and rock multi-instrumentalist, songwriter, and producer. Born in Ballyshannon, County Donegal,[3] and brought up in Cork, secondnameplaceholder formed the band Taste in the late 1960s and recorded solo albums throughout the 1970s and 1980s. His albums have sold over 30 million copies worldwide.[4][5]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   secondnameplaceholder received a liver transplant in 1995, but died of complications later that year in London at the age of 47.[6]\n                      firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder (born May 24, 1955) is an American singer-songwriter and author. She is the eldest daughter of country musician Johnny secondnameplaceholder and Vivian Liberto secondnameplaceholder Distin, Johnny secondnameplaceholder's first wife.[1] Although she is often classified as a country artist, her music draws on many genres, including folk, pop, rock, blues, and most notably Americana. In the 1980s, she had a string of genre-crossing singles that entered both the country and pop charts, the most commercially successful being her 1981 breakthrough hit "Seven Year Ache", which topped the U.S. country singles chart and reached the Top 30 on the U.S. pop chart.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                         In 1990, secondnameplaceholder released Interiors, a spare, introspective album which signaled a break from her pop country past.[2] The following year she ended her marriage and moved from Nashville to New York City where she continues to write, record, and perform, having since released six albums, written three books, and edited a collection of short stories. Her fiction and essays have been published in The New York Times, Rolling Stone, The Oxford American, New York Magazine, and other periodicals and collections.\n
 secondnameplaceholder won a Grammy Award in 1985 for "I Don't Know Why You Don't Want Me" and has received 12 other Grammy nominations.[3] She has had 11 No. 1 country hit singles, 21 Top 40 country singles, and two gold records. secondnameplaceholder was the 2014 recipient of Smithsonian magazine's American Ingenuity Award in the Performing Arts category. On February 8, 2015, secondnameplaceholder won three Grammy awards for Best Americana Album for The River & the Thread, Best American Roots Song with John Leventhal and Best American Roots Performance for A Feather's Not A Bird.[4] secondnameplaceholder was honored further in October that year, when she was inducted into the Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame.[5]\n

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Country Music Association Awards\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Grammy Awards \nTo date, secondnameplaceholder has been nominated for 15 Grammy Awards across four genre categories: Country, Folk, Pop and American Roots.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Country Music Association Awards\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Grammy Awards \nTo date, secondnameplaceholder has been nominated for 15 Grammy Awards across four genre categories: Country, Folk, Pop and American Roots.\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Grammy Awards \nTo date, secondnameplaceholder has been nominated for 15 Grammy Awards across four genre categories: Country, Folk, Pop and American Roots.\n                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   \n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder were  an English rock band formed in 1970 by Bryan Ferry—who became the band's lead singer and main songwriter—and bass guitarist Graham Simpson. The other longtime members were Phil Manzanera (guitar), Andy Mackay (saxophone and oboe), and Paul Thompson (drums and percussion). Other members included Brian Eno (synthesizer and 'treatments'), Eddie Jobson (synthesizer and violin), and John Gustafson (bass). Although the band took a break from group activities in 1976 and again in 1983, they reunited for a concert tour in 2001, and toured together intermittently over the next few years. Ferry frequently enlisted band members as session musicians for his solo releases.\n
 firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder became a successful act in Europe and Australia during the 1970s. This success began with their self-titled debut album in 1972.[8] The band pioneered more musically sophisticated elements of glam rock while significantly influencing early English punk music,[9] and provided a model for many new wave acts while innovating elements of electronic composition. The group also conveyed their distinctive brand of visual and musical sophistication with their focus on glamorous fashions.[1] Ferry and co-founding member Eno have had influential solo careers. Eno became one of the most significant British record producers of the late 20th century. Rolling Stone originally ranked firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder No. 98 on their greatest artists list  ("The Immortals – The 100 Greatest Artists of All Time"), but dropped the group from the list when they updated it in 2011.[10]\n
                                                                                                                                                        firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's final studio album was Avalon (1982), which was certified Platinum in the United States.[11] In 2005, the band began recording what would have become their ninth studio album—and their first album with Eno since 1973 (he wrote two songs for it and also played keyboards).[12] However, Ferry eventually announced that the material from these sessions would instead be released as a Ferry solo album, with Eno playing on “a couple of tracks”,[13] and that he believed the group would never again produce a record as firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder.[citation needed] The album was released in 2010 as the Ferry solo album Olympia. It featured contributions from Eno, Manzanera, and Mackay (amongst many other session players).\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   In 2011, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder played a series of 40th-anniversary shows, but since then they have been inactive as a performing entity.[14] In 2019, firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.[15][16]\n
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder were  an English rock band formed in 1970 by Bryan Ferry—who became the band's lead singer and main songwriter—and bass guitarist Graham Simpson. The other longtime members were Phil Manzanera (guitar), Andy Mackay (saxophone and oboe), and Paul Thompson (drums and percussion). Other members included Brian Eno (synthesizer and 'treatments'), Eddie Jobson (synthesizer and violin), and John Gustafson (bass). Although the band took a break from group activities in 1976 and again in 1983, they reunited for a concert tour in 2001, and toured together intermittently over the next few years. Ferry frequently enlisted band members as session musicians for his solo releases.\n
 firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder became a successful act in Europe and Australia during the 1970s. This success began with their self-titled debut album in 1972.[8] The band pioneered more musically sophisticated elements of glam rock while significantly influencing early English punk music,[9] and provided a model for many new wave acts while innovating elements of electronic composition. The group also conveyed their distinctive brand of visual and musical sophistication with their focus on glamorous fashions.[1] Ferry and co-founding member Eno have had influential solo careers. Eno became one of the most significant British record producers of the late 20th century. Rolling Stone originally ranked firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder No. 98 on their greatest artists list  ("The Immortals – The 100 Greatest Artists of All Time"), but dropped the group from the list when they updated it in 2011.[10]\n
                                                                                                                                                        firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder's final studio album was Avalon (1982), which was certified Platinum in the United States.[11] In 2005, the band began recording what would have become their ninth studio album—and their first album with Eno since 1973 (he wrote two songs for it and also played keyboards).[12] However, Ferry eventually announced that the material from these sessions would instead be released as a Ferry solo album, with Eno playing on “a couple of tracks”,[13] and that he believed the group would never again produce a record as firstnameplaceholder secondnameplaceholder.[citation needed] The album was released in 2010 as the Ferry solo album Olympia. It featured contributions from Eno, Manzanera, and Mackay (amongst many other session players).\n
